#â€‹756 â€” October 10, 2025

Read on the Web

JavaScript Weekly

â–¶Â Â Vite: The Documentary â€” From the same creators of the fantastic â–¶ï¸Â Node.js, â–¶ï¸Â Angular and â–¶ï¸Â React documentaries comes an up to date look at Vite, the build tool that has taken the JavaScript ecosystem by storm in recent years. Many luminaries make an appearance to tell their stories, including Evan You, Rich Harris, and Ryan Carniato. (39Â minutes.)

CultRepo

ğŸ’¡ In related news, Vite+ (VitePlus) has appeared, a future, more commercial offering of the Vite toolchain aimed at teams. More news on this next week.

Go from Monolith to Monorepo â€” Join Mike North for this course on architecting maintainable, fast and light codebases. You'll learn how to refactor a codebase into a TypeScript monorepo using tools like Nx and Lerna â€” covering dependencies, formatting, linting, performance andÂ more.

Frontend Masters sponsor

Introducing the React Foundation â€” At React Conf 2025 this week, it was announced that control of React and React Native is to be moved from Meta to an independent foundation supported by the Linux Foundation and initially backed by corporate members including Amazon, Expo, Meta, andÂ Microsoft.

Webster, Carroll, Savona and Alpert

ğŸ“º If you'd like to catch up with React Conf, you can now watch the â–¶ï¸Â dayÂ one and â–¶ï¸Â dayÂ two livestream recordings onÂ YouTube.

IN BRIEF:

  • Ready for a bit of experimental fun? Here's an implementation of pipeline-style composition (using |) in pure JavaScript thanks to Symbol.toPrimitive and some rather clever code.

  • ğŸ•¹ï¸ The JS13KGames gamedev event recently ended and here are 2025's winners for you to play or dig through the code for.

  • âš–ï¸ Deno, currently embroiled in a fight with Oracle over the JavaScript trademark, has served Oracle the first request for documents.

  • ğŸ¤– Mastra, a fast-growing TypeScript-based AI framework initially created by members of the Gatsby team, has raised a $13m seed round.

  • Nicholas C. Zakas shares what's coming up in ESLint v10.0.

RELEASES:

  • Next.js 16 Beta â€“ Turbopack support is now stable and the default bundler for Next.js apps, React 19.2 support is also baked in, React Compiler support is now stable, andÂ more.

  • Playwright 1.56 â€“ Microsoft's browser/Web automation library â€“ now with â–¶ï¸Â PlaywrightÂ Agents.

  • ESLint v9.37.0, VS Code September 2025

ğŸ“–Â  Articles and Videos

The Birth of Prettier â€” The author takes us back ten years to the genesis of Prettier, the popular opinionated, deterministic code formatter he co-created with James Long. Prettier effectively introduced and popularized the practice of fully-automated AST-based code formatting in the JavaScriptÂ ecosystem.

Christopher Chedeau (Vjeux)

15 Recent Node.js Features That Can Replace Popular npm Packages â€” Many features that once required third-party packages are now built into the runtimeÂ itself.

Lizz Parody

âš¡ Supercharge Postgres: 2PB Scale & 1.5T Metrics/Day â€” TigerData makes Postgres the fastest database for modern workloads: 2PB scale, 1.5T metrics/day, no blackÂ boxes.

TigerData sponsor

How to Group Arrays Without reduce() â€” A look at using Object.groupBy() and Map.groupBy()

Matt Smith

The History of Core Web Vitals â€” Addy tells the story behind Core Web Vitals, a popular set of metrics for measuring Web performance and its impact on userÂ experience.

Addy Osmani

ğŸ“„ How to Add Fast, Client-Side Search to Astro Static Sites â€“ JavaScript to theÂ rescue! Ivan Chepurin

ğŸ“„ Shipping Node.js Packages in 2025 â€“ A dense and helpful slidedeck from a talk given at last week's NordicJS event. Joyee Cheung

ğŸ“„ How to Animate WebGL Shaders with GSAP: Ripples, Reveals, and Dynamic Blur Effects Andrea Biason

ğŸ“„ Vue Basics: State Management in Vue David Adeneye Abiodun

ğŸ› Â Code & Tools

Viz.js 3.20: Work with Graphviz in the Browser â€” Graphviz is a suite of open source graph drawing tools of over 30 yearsâ€™ vintage. Viz.js is a WebAssembly Graphviz build that brings its functionality into the browser. GitHubÂ repo.

Michael Daines

EmbedPDF: A PDF Viewer That Integrates with Any JavaScript Project â€” No dependencies, supports any framework, and has features like themes, annotations, redaction, search, smooth scrolling, and more â€“ all available via a dev-friendly API. See the docs or try a liveÂ demo.

EmbedPDF

ğŸ¸ AI Agent Builder with All the Features, None of the Overhead â€” Shipping an agent-first web app? Use our template with all premium diagramming features and cut your dev time toÂ days.

JOINTJS sponsor

The Coinbase Design System (CDS) React Components Library â€” The team behind Coinbase has open sourced its component library for React and React Native. There are lots of neat effects in the components, such as this â€˜rolling numberâ€™ component.

Coinbase

Icebird: Read Apache Iceberg Tables in JavaScript â€” Iceberg is a high performance open-source format for large analyticÂ tables.

Hyperparam

resolve-lexicon: Resolve AT Lexicons Over the Network â€” Lexicon is a schema definition language used in the AT Protocol world.

Dan Abramov

  • react-map-gl 8.1 â€“ React friendly API wrapper around MapboxGL JS.Â (Demo.)

  • ğŸ”® Tarot.js 1.0 â€“ Library for creating and managing tarot cards andÂ decks.

  • PlayCanvas glTF Viewer 5.6 â€“ 3D model viewer supporting glTF 2.0 andÂ PLY.

  • Vue-multiselect 3.4 â€“ Select/multiselect/tagging component forÂ Vue.

  • Reactylon 3.2 â€“ Babylon.js-powered XR framework forÂ React.

  • Marked 16.4 â€“ Fast Markdown compilerÂ /Â parser.

  • Pixi.js 8.14 â€“ Fast, flexible 2D WebGLÂ renderer.

  • Javet 5.0 â€“ Embed Node.js and V8 intoÂ Java.

ğŸ“°Â Classifieds

HIRING NOWğŸ•³ï¸ ğŸ¥Š: At Holepunch we maintain 2000+ OSS npm packages, make the JS runtime Bare to build the P2P Internet. Real tech, Real impact. JoinÂ us!

Meticulous automatically creates and maintains an E2E UI test suite with zero developer effort. Relied on by Notion, Dropbox, Wiz, Lattice,Â etc.

ğŸ“¢Â  Elsewhere in the ecosystem

A roundup of some other interesting stories in the broader landscape:

  • ğŸ‘ The Firefox team has put together a way for you to give input on which Interop proposals matter the most to you (above). Go to the Interop Feature Ranking site (GitHub account required) and drag the web platform features that matter most for you to the top.

  • ğŸ”’ JavaScript security expert Liran Tal has put together a list of npm security best practices to considerÂ adopting.

  • ğŸ–¼ï¸ Mirrow is an interesting way to create and animate SVGs using a custom CSS-esque DSL in an attempt to promote SVGs from merely being static assets to something you can manage in a more code-likeÂ way. Check out the Mirrow playground toÂ experiment.

  • We've all heard of vibe coding but Simon Willison wonders if LLMs used properly to produce code that someone confidently stand behind could be considered 'vibe engineering'?

  • Talking of vibes, Heroku is taking a step into the world of AI-powered app building with Heroku Vibes.

  • Caden Parker presents a look at parallelizing cellular automata using WebGPU computeÂ shaders.

#â€‹755 â€” October 3, 2025

Read on the Web

JavaScript Weekly

The State of JavaScript 2025 Survey â€” Each year, Devographics runs an epic survey of as many JavaScript community members as it can and turns the results into an interesting report on the state of the ecosystem â€“ hereâ€™s the results from 2024. If you have the time, fill it in, especially as they format it in a way where you can actually learn about stuff as youÂ go.

Devographics

React 19.2 Released â€” The third release in a year for React, this time introducing new features like <Activity /> (a way to hide and restore the UI and internal state of its children), useEffectEvent, and improvements to Chrome DevTools' performance profiles so you can see more about Reactâ€™s scheduling and the tree of components itâ€™s working with. Oh, and how about partialÂ pre-rendering?

The React Team

Donâ€™t miss The AI Security Developers Challenge at DevSecCon on Oct 22, 2025 â€” Participate in the hands-on developer challenge workshop ğŸ’»at DevSecCon and get a chance to team up with industry experts from around the globe ğŸŒ. Register for free and walk away with practical tips you can apply directly to your projectsÂ ğŸš€.

Snyk sponsor

IN BRIEF:

  • Monthly roundups aplenty from the Svelte project, team Astro, and Viteland!

  • It was recently discovered that Electron-based apps were causing system-wide lag on macOS 26/Tahoe due to changes in a private API. Electron 38.2, 37.6 and 36.9.2 fix the bug.

  • ğŸ“º The creators of popular documentaries â–¶ï¸Â about Vue.js, â–¶ï¸Â React, and â–¶ï¸Â Node.js are about to release a new one about Vite. It lands next week; â–¶ï¸Â here's a 1-minute teaser trailer.

  • The newly relaunched JSConf event returns to Maryland on October 14-16. Tickets are still available and they gave us a JSCONF25NEWSLETTER code which gives a discount. (Note: We have no financial relationship with the event.)

  • ğŸ¤– Google AI Studio has added the ability to generate Angular apps.

  • The release of Bun 1.3, expected yesterday, has been pushed back to nextÂ Monday.

RELEASES:

  • Anime.js 4.2 â€“ Powerful JavaScript animationÂ engine.

  • npm-check-updates 19.0 â€“ Find newer versions of packages dependencies than your package.jsonÂ allows.

  • pnpm 10.18, Oxlint 1.19, Bun 1.2.23, Deno 2.5.3

ğŸ“–Â  Articles and Videos

How Deno Protects Against npm Exploits â€” The maintainers of the Deno runtime reflect on the recent npm ecosystem security issues and show off how Denoâ€™s non-permissive explicit â€˜secure by defaultâ€™ model canÂ help.

Andy Jiang

Cleaning House in Nx Monorepo: How I Removed 120 Unused Deps Safely â€” Another win (mostly) for Knip, a tool that helps you declutter projects by finding unusedÂ dependencies.

John James

Tests Are Dead. Meticulous Is Here â€” Meticulous automatically creates and maintains an E2E UI test suite with zero developerÂ effort.

Meticulous sponsor

You Can Now Make PS2 Games in JavaScript â€” Last week we mentioned running JavaScript in MS-DOS but you can take it to Sonyâ€™s Playstation 2 as well using a system built upon QuickJS.

JSLegendDev

How to Detect Safari and iOS Versions from JavaScript â€” Naturally, progressive enhancement is the best policy, but if you needÂ to..

Evgeniy Valyaev

Mastering npx: A Cheatsheet for npm and Node Power Users â€” Youâ€™ve almost certainly used the npx command to easily run a command from an npm package (either local or remote) â€“ itâ€™s easy to use, but npx has a couple of other features and options to keep inÂ mind.

Liran Tal

ğŸ“„ Why Next.js Falls Short on Software Engineering Harshal Patil

ğŸ“„ @ts-ignore is Almost Always the Worst Option â€“ Prefer any and @ts-expect-error, says theÂ author. Evan Hahn

ğŸ“„ I Want to Intercept Boolean Coercion for Objects in JavaScript Zach Leatherman

ğŸ› Â Code & Tools

qjs: Run JavaScript in Go using QuickJS and Wazero â€” A new Cgo-free JavaScript runtime option for integrating JavaScript into apps written in Go. It uses a fork of QuickJS thatâ€™s compiled to WebAssembly and then run usingÂ Wazero.

Nguyen Ngoc Phuong and Contributors

ğŸ’¡ If you happen to be a Go developer, we have a sister newsletter for that!

Diagramming Library for the Enterprise? Use JointJS â€” Cut dev time 12x with JointJS, the most feature-rich diagramming library trusted by Fortune 100Â companies.

JointJS sponsor

SpaceTime 7.11: A Lightweight Timezone Library â€” Use this to calculate times in other timezones. Has a Moment-like API but is immutable. No dependencies. GitHubÂ repo.

Spencer Kelly

Jeasx: A Lightweight SSR Framework That Uses JSX â€” A server side rendering framework built on top of JSX and Fastify. It doesnâ€™t use React, but if you want to keep using JSX while keeping your server side lightweight, itâ€™s an option. The JSX functionality is provided by the authorâ€™s jsx-async-runtime package. v1.9 was justÂ released.

Maik Jablonski

ğŸ“ŠÂ Vue ECharts 8.0: Vue.js Component for Apache ECharts â€” Apache ECharts is a popular, powerful JavaScript charting library weâ€™ve linked many times and this project makes it easier to use in Vue.js apps. v8.0 upgrades to ECharts 6.0. GitHubÂ repo.

GU Yiling and ECOMFE

modern-tar: Zero-Dependency Streaming tar Parser and Writer â€” As in the classic tar archiveÂ format.

Ayuhito

  • ğŸ—“ï¸ Color Calendar 2.0 â€“ Add interactive events calendars to aÂ page.

  • Skia Canvas 3.0 â€“ GPU-powered 2D vector canvas graphics forÂ Node.

  • CKEditor5 47.0 â€“ Popular commercial rich text editorÂ framework.

  • Verdaccio 6.2 â€“ Lightweight local private npmÂ registry.

  • BlockNote 0.40 â€“ 'Notion-style' block-basedÂ editor.

  • NodeBB 4.6 â€“ Node.js based forumÂ system.

ğŸ“°Â Classifieds

ğŸš€ FastCI: How to double the speed of your Continuous Integration with a 2-minuteÂ setup.

At Holepunch we maintain 2000+ OSS npm packages, make the JS runtime Bare to build the P2P Internet. Real tech, Real impact. JoinÂ us!

ğŸ•°Â Â ICYMI (Some older stuff that may catch your eye...)

ğŸ›£ï¸ Sean C Davis runs through strategies for managing routes in JavaScript projects â€” good, practical advice for establishing a consistent workflow and improve overall maintainability.

ğŸ¦† Remember Duck Hunt for the NES? Well, â–¶ï¸ here's a lengthy video looking at how to recreate it inÂ TypeScript.

ğŸ› ï¸ Chizaram Ken runs through a handful of reasons why your Next.js app may be slow, along with some possibleÂ fixes.

ğŸ˜—Â Â And a weird note to end on..

Have you ever wanted to program by whistling? Now you can. Velato is a JavaScript-inspired esoteric language designed to be written entirely by whistling and you can give it a go in your browser right now. I struggled with it, but you might have more luck (it doesn't seem to like Safari, forÂ starters).

Velato was built by Daniel Temkin, the author of Forty-Four Esolangs, a new book, published by MIT Press, about an artist's take on creating esoteric programming languages.

Read on the Web

JavaScript Weekly

Give Your AI Eyes: Introducing Chrome DevTools MCP â€” The Chrome team has released an MCP server for Chrome DevTools, enabling agents like Claude Code or OpenAI Codex to use the DevTools to debug and analyze the performance and behavior of your webapps (or even just to automate the use of Chrome generally). Addy does a great job of explaining the potentialÂ here.

Addy Osmani

AI Code Reviews Meet CLI Coding Agents â€” CodeRabbit CLI brings instant code reviews directly to your terminal, integrating with Claude Code, Cursor CLI, and other AI agents. While they generate code, CodeRabbit ensures it's production-ready - catching bugs, security issues, and hallucinations before they hit yourÂ codebase.

CodeRabbit sponsor

GitHub's Plan for a More Secure npm Supply Chain â€” In direct response to the recent npm ecosystem supply chain attacks of recent weeks, GitHubâ€™s senior director of security research has outlined steps GitHub is taking, including blocking the upload of packages featuring the patterns of the recent malware, hardening package publication, and promoting the use of trustedÂ publishing.

Xavier RenÃ©-Corail (GitHub)

IN BRIEF:

  • Netscape Navigator 2.0 Beta was released 30 years ago â€“ it was notable as the first browser to include JavaScript support.

  • The agenda of this week's TC39 meeting where several proposals were advanced, including Import Bytes, Iterator Chunking, and Array.prototype.pushAll.

  • The Chrome team expects Chrome/Chromium's support for the Temporal API to land in Chromium 144 (the current stable version is 140).

  • InfoQ shares an update on the features of Preact 11 beta, the recently released update to the popular lightweight ReactÂ alternative.

  • The IEEE has released its list of the top programming languages of 2025 with JavaScript and TypeScript coming in at #6 and #7Â respectively.

RELEASES:

  • pnpm 10.17 â€“ The new minimumReleaseAgeExclude now supports patterns to exclude groups of packages from minimum release ageÂ checks.

  • Astro 5.14 - Boasts "a bumper harvest of features and DX improvements to warm the cockles of your heart."

  • Node.js v24.9.0 (Current) and v22.20.0 (LTS)

  • Nuxt UI 4.0, PostgreSQL 18.0, ESLint v9.36.0

From Steam to Floppy: Porting Modern TypeScript to Run on DOS â€” The creator of a DOS-inspired programming game (available on Steam) wanted to try and get the game running on real DOS. Thanks to jSH, a JavaScript engine for DOS, it was kinda do-able.

Jimbly / Dashing Strike

NPM Security Best Practices â€” An extensive list of best practices, techniques, and ideas to consider for making your use of the npm packaging ecosystem and its tooling moreÂ secure.

Boda

Implementing Authentication and Session Management in Next.js â€” Learn how to integrate user sign-up, sign-in, and protected routes into your Next.js app with modern authÂ practices.

Clerk sponsor

JSON is Not JSON Across Languages â€” If you use JSON to communicate between systems built in different languages, beware. Different libraries with varying opinions can cause â€œsome of the most soul-crushing debugging experiences in softwareÂ development.â€

Dochia CLI

TanStack Start v1 Release Candidate â€” TanStackâ€™s attempt at a full-stack TanStack Router-powered framework has reached a v1.0 release candidate thatâ€™s expected to be largely the same as its eventual 1.0 release. â€œItâ€™s the next chapter in building type-safe, high-performance React apps without the heavyÂ abstractions.â€

Roles Get Messy Fast. WorkOS RBAC Keeps Access in Check â€” Define roles, group permissions, and sync with SSO and SCIM. Manage access with clean APIs and a powerfulÂ dashboard.

Cap'n Web: A New RPC System for Browsers and Web Servers â€” A â€˜spiritual siblingâ€™ to Capâ€™n Proto, an RPC protocol created by one of the same authors. However, Capâ€™n Webâ€™s underlying serialization is human-readable, focused on integrating well with JS runtimes, and works over HTTP, WebSocket, and postMessage() out-of-the-box.

Nick van Dyke

Meticulous automatically creates and maintains an E2E UI test suite with zero developer effort. Relied on by Dropbox, Wiz, Lattice, Bilt Rewards,Â etc.

ğŸš€ Next week: JetBrains JavaScript Day 2025! A free online event full of talks & live Q&A with experts from the JS community. Donâ€™t missÂ it!

ğŸ§Â Learning web development with Dr.Â Axel

Over the past couple of months the esteemed Dr. Axel Rauschmayer has been working on a valuable series of beginner-friendly posts on a range of web development topics, with a heavy focus on JavaScript. He pitches the series as a way to teach people "who have never programmed how to create web apps with JavaScript".

These are all excellent primers/refreshers, and ideal for sharing with those early in their web development journey. Here are some of the highlights so far:

  • Working with numbers, variables, and functions, and strings and methods.
  • Booleans, comparisons and if statements and loops.
  • Digging into plain objects, Arrays, Maps, and exceptions.
  • An introduction to frontend frameworks using Preact.
  • Installing npm packages and bundling.
  • Promises and async functions.

P.S. Don't go JSON waterfalls..

item.description:
ã€

#â€‹753 â€” September 19, 2025

Read on the Web

JavaScript Weekly

The 'Shai-Hulud' npm Supply Chain Attack Rumbles On â€” Now named after a term for the sandworms of the Dune universe, the ongoing malicious supply chain attack affecting the npm ecosystem has grown in scale with hundreds of packages affected in an attempt to exfiltrate tokens and secrets from developersâ€™ machines.

Pandya, van der Zee, and Brown (Socket)

The story above has triggered a wave of responses and mitigations:

  • pnpm 10.16 has been released with support for delaying dependency updates using a minimumReleaseAge option â€“ explained in more depth here. We expect to see more tools adopt similar features in dueÂ course.

  • In 'a meditation on npm supply chain attacks', Tane Piper points a finger at Microsoft'sÂ role.

  • Drew DeVault talks about a better future for JavaScript 'that won't happen', focusing on the systemic changes needed to improve theÂ situation.

FlexGrid by Wijmo: The Industry-Leading JavaScript Datagrid â€” A fast and flexible DataGrid for building modern web apps. Key features and virtualized rendering are included in the core grid module. Pick & choose special features to keep your app small. Built for JavaScript, extended to Angular, React, andÂ Vue.

Wijmo From MESCIUS sponsor

âš–ï¸Â Deno Asks: 'Help Us Raise $200k to Free JavaScript from Oracle' â€” The term JavaScript(â„¢) is actually an Oracle trademark, but Ryan Dahl and Deno are attempting to fight that and are raising funds to get through the all-important discovery phase of the cancellationÂ petition.

Ryan Dahl (Deno)

IN BRIEF:

  • The WebAssembly 3.0 standard is now 'live' (and already ships with most browsers) with various features that should improve JS interoperability, including garbage collection, tail calls, exception handling, and ways to manipulate JavaScript stringsÂ directly.

  • â–¶ï¸ Vue's Evan You was recently interviewed by Nuno Maduro of the Laravel project about his background at Google, how Vue.js was first created, the relationship between Next.js and Nuxt, and his current work with void(0).

  • We recently mentioned Andromeda as being the newest JavaScript runtime to appear, but now there's Ion, a runtime aimed at bringing a JavaScript engine into Rust programs.

  • Webflow has donated $150k to the Astro project.

RELEASES:

  • Safari 26.0 has been released alongside macOS 26.0, iOS 26.0, etc. Along with numerous CSS enhancements and a new <model> element for embedding 3D models onto web pages, every site can now "be a web app" on iOS and iPadOS if a user adds it to their home screen.

  • Bun v1.2.22 â€“ Stack traces now include asynchronous call frames, there's Bun.YAML.stringify to turn objects into YAML, bundler & minifier improvements, andÂ more.

  • As of React Router 7.9.0, the long-awaited middleware feature is now stable.

ğŸ“–Â  Articles

Fetch Streams are Great, But Not for Measuring Upload/Download Progress â€” Fetch upload streams seem well-suited for tracking the progress of uploads, but as Jake notes â€œjust because stuff is taken from the stream doesnâ€™t mean itâ€™s yet been sent over the networkâ€. He also touches on an issue relating to measuring download progress using responseÂ streams.

Jake Archibald

Moving Off of TypeScript (We Love You, TypeScript) â€” An interesting tale from an engineering team that has decided to throw in the towel on its 2.5 million lines of TypeScript, instead migrating to .NET and C#. React will remain on their frontend, however.

Chander Ramesh

Secure Your Agentic Apps with Auth for GenAI â€” Secure your agentic apps with features like User Authentication for AI agents, Token Vault, and more with Auth0â€™s Auth for GenAI (exclusively in DeveloperÂ Preview).

Auth0 sponsor

'React Won by Default â€“ And It's Killing Frontend Innovation' â€” An opinionated React thought-piece thatâ€™s provoked much discussion this week by poking at the downsides and inertia caused by â€˜the React-by-default mindset.â€™

Loren Stewart

ğŸ“„ Beyond The Horizon: How Angular is Embracing AI for Next-Gen Apps â€“ An update direct from the AngularÂ team. Simona Cotin (Angular)

ğŸ“„ Solid.js vs. React: A Developer's Perspective â€“ â€œSolid has been a breath of fresh air and it has opened my eyes to what React could be, but probably never willÂ be.â€ Alem Tuzlak

ğŸ“„ Creating an Immersive 3D Weather Visualization with React Three Fiber Carter Rink

ğŸ› Â Code & Tools

npm-check-updates 18.2: Update package.json Dependencies to Latest Versions â€” That is, as opposed to the specified versions. Includes a handy -i interactive mode so you can look at potential upgrades and then opt in to them one by one. v18.2 adds a â€˜cooldownâ€™ feature to help protect against supply chain attacks by requiring package versions to be published at least the given number of days before considering them forÂ upgrade.

Raine Revere

Expo SDK 54 Released: A Big One for React Native Developers â€” The Expo framework continues its rapid ascent in the world of React Native with precompiled React Native iOS builds (for much shorter build times), iOS 26 and Liquid Glass support, and the use of React Native 0.81 and React 19.1. The new Expo File System has also becomeÂ stable.

Hughes and Vatne (Expo)

Ready to Increase Your Conversions? Get Started with Free Trials â€” Free Trials are now available through Clerk Billing. Stop building trial logic, cancellation flows, and upgradeÂ paths.

Clerk sponsor

ğŸ¦‹Â BlueSky Likes: Flexible Components for Displaying BlueskyÂ Likes â€” Includes two custom element components: bluesky-likes and bluesky-likers to display the number of likes and a group of avatars of those who liked a post respectively. LiveÂ demo.

Lea Verou

Svedit: A Tiny Library for Building Rich Content Editors with Svelte â€” Enables you to model your content in JSON, render it with custom Svelte components, and edit directly in the layout. GitHubÂ repo.

Michael Aufreiter

  • TypeBox 1.0 â€“ A runtime type system that creates in-memory JSON Schema objects that infer as TypeScriptÂ types.

  • ğŸ™‚ Vue Frimousse v0.1.3 â€“ Unstyled, composable emoji picker forÂ Vue.

  • wait-on 9.0 â€“ CLI utility and Node API to wait for files, ports, sockets, and http(s) resources to becomeÂ available.

  • ğŸ—“ï¸ DayPicker 9.10 â€“ React component for creating date pickers, calendars, and dateÂ inputs.

  • Wasp 0.18 â€“ Wasp is a Rails-like framework using Node, React &Â Prisma.

  • pretty-ms 9.3 â€“ Convert milliseconds to a human readableÂ string.

  • npm-publish 4.0 â€“ GitHub Action to publish packages toÂ npm.

  • Hexo 8.0 â€“ Popular blog framework/Â generator.

  • Fresh 2.1 â€“ Deno-powered WebÂ framework.

ğŸ“°Â Classifieds

Meticulous automatically creates and maintains an E2E UI test suite with zero developer effort. Relied on by Dropbox, Wiz, Lattice, Bilt Rewards,Â etc.

Go beyond caching. Redis 8.2 handles 5x more data with 150 new commands and 8 new data structures vs 7.2. Get startedÂ today.

â­ JetBrains JavaScript Day 2025 brings insights from experts like Ryan Carniato, Kent C. Dodds, and more. Free & online â€“ tune in on OctÂ 2!

ğŸÂ Some Bonus Items

  • IINA is a popular, open-source media player for macOS and it has just added a JavaScript-based plugin system to let users extend itsÂ functionality.

  • Which npm Package Has the Largest Version Number? Armed with Bun and access to the npm registry's data, a developer set out to satisfy his curiosity, discovering a variety of winners (depending on how you define â€˜versionâ€™ andÂ â€˜largestâ€™).

  • ğŸ“‚ Want to download MDN for offline reference? The creator of the Dash macOS documentation browser shares some archive files of MDN's documentation covering areas like JavaScript, CSS, HTML andÂ SVG.

  • Bocoup's Mike Pennisi talks about the Web's most tolerated feature (yet an oft-forgotten one), namely the zoom CSS property.
